Knowledge Point: The subject marker is obligatory, whether the subject noun is used in the same clause as the verb, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref452540561}), or is absent from the clause, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref74906677}).\largerpage
Content 1: \gsrc ècí cìpùrà càcôːkì | \gll e-cí ci-pura ci-a-cóːk-i | \gls AUG-DEM.I7 NP7-chair SM7-PST-break-NPST.PFV | \glt ‘This chair is broken.’

Knowledge Point: When the subject noun is not used in the same clause, the subject marker still agrees in noun class with the intended subject noun. In (\ref{bkm:Ref452543253}), the class 7 subject marker ci- in the verb cìbònàhàrá ‘it looked’ refers back to the noun phrase cìmbòtwé cìnênè ‘a big frog’, that was introduced in the previous sentence. In (\ref{bkm:Ref452543245}), the people that the speaker describes are standing close by and can therefore be inferred from the physical surroundings.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc bàkwèsì bàkòndòr’ óbùjwàrà | \gll ba-kwesi ba-kondor-á̲ o-bu-jwara | \gls SM2-have SM2-brew-FV AUG-NP14-beer | \glt ‘They’re brewing beer.’

Knowledge Point: Subject agreement becomes more complex when the subject consists of coordinated nouns of different noun classes. Different languages employ different gender resolution rules, i.e. the strategies which determine agreement with coordinated noun phrases, which may be based on (a combination of) syntactic and semantic criteria \citep{Corbett1991}. In Fwe, class 8 agreement is used, at least if both nouns are non-human, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref451258925}) and (\ref{bkm:Ref451258926}). No distinction is made between animate and inanimate non-human nouns. Data on the agreement patterns of coordinated nouns referring to humans are limited. Although this requires further research, it may suggest that Fwe tends to avoid such constructions.
Content 1: \gsrc zìzyùnì nàbànkûkù zìzárà màyîː | \gll zi-zyuni na=ba-nkúku zi-zá̲r-a ma-yíː | \gls NP8-bird COM=NP2-chicken SM8-give.birth-FV NP6-egg | \glt ‘Birds and chickens lay eggs.’
Content 2: \gsrc mwêzì nèzyûbà mùwírú ꜝzínà | \gll mu-ézi ne=∅-zyúba mu-∅-wirú zi-iná | \gls NP3-moon COM=NP5-sun NP18-NP5-sky SM8-be_at | \glt ‘The moon and the sun are in the sky.’

Knowledge Point: Object markers can only be used when no object noun is used in the same clause. The noun class of the object marker corresponds to that of the intended noun. (\ref{bkm:Ref448142515}) is the answer to a question about ngùbò ‘blankets’; as this is a noun of class 10, the class 10 object marker is used.
Content 1: \gsrc ndàzíhîndì ndìkàzìsânzà | \gll ndi-a-zí-hind-i ndi-ka-ziH-sá̲nz-a | \gls SM1SG-PST-OM10-take-NPST.PFV SM1SG-DIST-OM10-wash-FV | \glt ‘I took them to wash them.’

Knowledge Point: An object marker is obligatory when the intended noun is not in the same clause as the verb. This is the case, for instance, with dislocated objects, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref452554600}), where a constituent is moved to the left periphery of a sentence to function as a topic.
Content 1: \gsrc òrú rùzyîmbò kàndìrúꜝshákì | \gll o-rú ru-zyímbo ka-ndi-rú-shak-í̲ | \gls AUG-DEM.I11 NP11-song NEG-SM1SG-OM11-like-NEG | \glt ‘This song, I don’t like it.’

Knowledge Point: Constituents can also be moved out of a clause to the right periphery as a way of definiteness marking. When right dislocation targets object constituents, they retain their canonical post-verbal position, but require the use of an object marker of the verb, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref445977500}--\ref{bkm:Ref99093552}).
Content 1: \gsrc ndìzìsháká ꜝzí nswì | \gll ndi-ziH-shak-á̲ zí N-swi | \gls SM1SG-OM10-like-FV DEM.I10 NP10-fish | \glt ‘I like these fish.’
Content 2: \gsrc ndàyíbàrì èyí mbùkà | \gll ndi-a-í-bar-i e-í N-buka | \gls SM1SG-PST-OM9-read-NPST.PFV AUG-DEM.I9 NP9-book | \glt ‘I’ve read this book.’

Knowledge Point: For a discussion of left and right dislocation, and a more detailed analysis of post-verbal objects with an object marker as a case of right dislocation, see chapter \ref{bkm:Ref99093567}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: A ditransitive verb can have multiple object markers, which appear in a fixed order: the object marker for the benefactive object appears closer to the stem than the object marker for the theme object. This is shown in (\ref{bkm:Ref491427919}), where the class 2 object marker referring to the benefactive object (‘for her’) appears closer to the stem than the class 13 object marker referring to the theme object (‘them’; in this case, the speaker is referring to dishes).
Content 1: \ea | \glll àtùbàsànzírà | \gll a-tuH-baH-sanz-ir-á̲ | \gls SM\textsubscript{1}-OM\textsubscript{13}-OM\textsubscript{2}-wash-APPL-FV

Knowledge Point: Verbs can take up to three object markers, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref491427907}). I was unable to come up with a suitable context in which four or more object markers might be warranted; possibly, given the right context, such constructions might be acceptable.
Content 1: \gsrc cìmùndìsúndîrè | \gll ciH-mu-ndi-suHnd-í̲r-e | \gls OM7-OM1-OM1SG-show-APPL-PFV.SBJV | \glt ‘Show it to her/him for me.’

Knowledge Point: Multiple object markers are not allowed when two or more object markers refer to an inanimate object. This is illustrated with the sentence in (\ref{bkm:Ref488927201}), containing two inanimate objects. It is possible to express either of these objects with an object marker, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref74907372}) and (\ref{bkm:Ref74907373}), but not both, as the ungrammaticality of (\ref{bkm:Ref74907374}) shows.
Content 1: \gsrc ndìzyàːkìr’ ómùndáré ꜝwángù cìòngò | \gll ndi-zyaːHk-ir-á̲ o-mu-ndaré u-angú ci-ongo | \gls SM1SG-build-APPL-FV AUG-NP3-maize PP3-POSS1SG NP7-storage | \glt ‘I am building a storage for my maize.’
Content 2: \gsrc ndìcìzyàːkìr’ ómùndárè | \gll ndi-ciH-zyaːHk-ir-á̲ o-mu-ndaré | \gls SM1SG-OM7-build-APPL-FV AUG-NP3-maize | \glt ‘I am building it for the maize.’
Content 3: \gsrc ndìùzyàːkìr’ écìòngò | \gll ndi-uH-zyaːHk-ir-á̲ e-ci-ongo | \gls SM1SG-OM3-build-APPL-FV AUG-NP7-storage | \glt ‘I am building a storage for it.’

Knowledge Point: In addition to object markers for noun classes and first and second person, Fwe has a reflexive prefix kí- (Zambian Fwe) / rí- (Namibian Fwe) which is used in the same position as the object marker. Examples of the use of the reflexive are given in (\ref{bkm:Ref451865865}--\ref{bkm:Ref445986266}).
Content 1: \gsrc ndàkírèmèkì | \gll ndi-a-kí-remek-i | \gls SM1SG-PST-REFL-hurt-NPST.PFV | \glt ‘I’ve hurt myself.’
Content 2: \gsrc àtàtìk’ ókùrínyàyà kùrínyàyà | \gll a-tatik-á o-ku-rí-nyay-a ku-rí-nyay-a | \gls SM1-start-FV AUG-INF-REFL-scratch-FV INF-REFL-scratch-FV | \glt ‘She starts to scratch herself, scratch herself.’

Knowledge Point: The reflexive prefix can be combined with an emphatic reflexive, consisting of the nominal root íni, with the lexical meaning ‘owner’, and an agreement prefix. íni is inflected for number, e.g. class 1 mw-înì for singular and class 2 b-ênì for plural. In addition, an appositive prefix is used that is co-referential with the verb’s subject (see \sectref{bkm:Ref492039371} on appositives). Examples of emphatic reflexives are given in (\ref{bkm:Ref492039232}--\ref{bkm:Ref492039233}).
Content 1: \gsrc ndìrìbwènè ndémwìnì | \gll ndi-riH-bweHne nde-mw-ini | \gls SM1SG-REFL-see.STAT APP1SG-NP1-owner | \glt ‘I see myself.’
Content 2: \gsrc twàkíbònì tùbênì | \gll tu-a-kí-bon-i tu-ba-íni | \gls SM1PL-PST-REFL-see-NPST.PFV APP1PL-NP2-self | \glt ‘We see ourselves.’

Knowledge Point: When the subject is not a first or second person, the nominal root íni is marked for noun class agreement with the subject, and an anaphoric demonstrative is used, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99093781}--\ref{bkm:Ref99093782}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The prefix kí-/rí- is also used with a reciprocal meaning, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99093796}--\ref{bkm:Ref99093797}).
Content 1: \gsrc tùrìshákà | \gll tu-riH-shak-á̲ | \gls SM1PL-REFL-love-FV | \glt ‘We love each other.’
Content 2: \gsrc màmésàjì bákìŋòrérà | \gll N-ma-mésaji bá̲-kiH-ŋoHr-er-á̲ | \gls COP-NP6-message SM2.REL-REFL-write-APPL-FV | \glt ‘It’s messages that they write to each other.’

Knowledge Point: Reflexive/reciprocal polysemy is not uncommon in languages, as both express that the agent of the action is simultaneously the patient. In the Bantu languages of zones H, K and R reciprocal and reflexive are expressed by the same pre-stem morpheme (\citealt{SchadebergBostoen2019}: 183). Outside these zones, many Bantu languages use a reflex of the reciprocal *-an to express reciprocal meaning. In Fwe, this suffix is all but gone, though speakers can still produce forms with \nobreakdash-an when prompted (see \sectref{bkm:Ref492040534}). When necessary, speakers can differentiate the reciprocal and reflexive meanings of the prefix rí-/kí- by adding the emphatic reflexive \-íni (see (\ref{bkm:Ref99093781}--\ref{bkm:Ref99093782})).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The reflexive prefix kí-/rí- is similar to object markers in a number of ways. The reflexive and object markers make use of the same slot in the verb, directly before the verb root. Like most object markers, the reflexive prefix has a high tone, which is deleted in the same TAM constructions (see \sectref{bkm:Ref71539267} on melodic tone). This is illustrated in (\ref{bkm:Ref445989915}--\ref{bkm:Ref445989917}), which show that the high tone of the object marker and the high tone of the reflexive prefix are maintained in the infinitive, but deleted in the present, a construction which deletes underlying high tones.
Content 1: \gsrc kùbáshàkà | \gll ku-bá-shak-a | \gls INF-OM2-love-FV | \glt ‘to love them’
Content 2: \gsrc tùrìshákà | \gll tu-riH-shak-á̲ | \gls SM1PL-REFL-love-FV | \glt ‘We love each other.’

Knowledge Point: Like object markers, the reflexive can co-occur with another object marker in ditransitive verbs, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99094122}).
Content 1: \gsrc bàcìrìshúmínìnìtè mwívùmò | \gll ba-ciH-riH-shumí̲n-in-ite mú-e-∅-vumo | \gls SM2-OM7-REFL-tie-APPL-STAT NP18-AUG-NP5-stomach | \glt ‘He has tied it around his waist.’

Knowledge Point: The locative clitic is the last morpheme in the verb: it appears after derivational suffixes, such as the applicative suffix -ir in (\ref{bkm:Ref448143628}), and after inflectional suffixes, such as the habitual -ang and the final vowel suffix -a in (\ref{bkm:Ref451261148}).
Content 1: \gsrc ndìfùtàtìrákò | \gll ndi-fuHtat-ir-a=kó̲ | \gls SM1SG-turn_back-APPL-FV=LOC17 | \glt ‘I turn my back towards it.’
Content 2: \gsrc kàtùnákùzíbìkàngàkò | \gll ka-tu-náku-zí-bik-ang-a=ko | \gls PST.IPFV-SM1PL-HAB-OM1PLput-HAB-FV=LOC17 | \glt ‘We usually put them there.’

Knowledge Point: When used with a reduplicated verb stem, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99094143}), the locative clitic is not reduplicated, even though the verb stem is reduplicated together with its inflectional suffixes, providing further evidence for its clitic status.
Content 1: \gsrc ndàyèndíyèndìkò | \gll ndi-a-endí̲-end-i=ko | \gls SM1SG-PST-PL2-go-PST=LOC17 | \glt ‘I kept going there.’

Knowledge Point: Phonologically, the locative clitic is fully integrated into the verb to which it attaches. Locative clitics influence the placement of melodic tone and penultimate lengthening. In the present construction, for instance, a melodic tone is assigned to the final mora of the verb, which retracts to the preceding mora in phrase-final position. The examples in (\ref{bkm:Ref505879591}) and (\ref{exampleiknockonit}) show that in determining the penultimate syllable, the locative clitic is also counted.
Content 1: \gsrc ndìngòngótà | \gll ndi-ngoHngot-á̲ | \gls SM1SG-knock-FV | \glt ‘I knock.’

Knowledge Point: Locative clitics are never used for referring to a locative noun phrase in the same clause, but only to locations that are introduced in the earlier discourse. An example is given in (\ref{bkm:Ref448144029}), an utterance consisting of two clauses, each with their own inflected verb. The noun cì-pùrà ‘chair’ is introduced in the first clause, and the verb of the second clause uses a locative clitic =ho to refer back to it.
Content 1: \gsrc mùbàhé cìpùrà bàkáréhò | \gll mu-baH-ha-é̲ ci-pura ba-kar-e=hó̲ | \gls SM2PL-OM2-give-PFV.SBJV NP7-chair SM2-sit-PFV.SBJV=LOC16 | \glt ‘Give her a chair, so she may sit on it.’

Knowledge Point: The three locative clitics each have their own semantics. The class 16 locative clitic =ho is used to refer to movement away from, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref446065313}), a location on, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref446065314}), or a more general location, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref446065854}).
Content 1: \gsrc ènzâsì zàkùrí kùǀásàùkàhò | \gll e-N-zási zi-aku-rí ku-ǀás-a-uk-a=ho | \gls AUG-NP10-spark SM10-NPST.IPFV-be INF-sparkle-PL1-SEP.INTR-FV=LOC16 | \glt ‘Sparks were flying from it.’
Content 2: \gsrc ndàngóngòtìhò | \gll ndi-a-ngóngot-i=ho | \gls SM1SG-PST-knock-PST=LOC16 | \glt ‘I knocked on it.’
Content 3: \gsrc tàbènáhò | \gll ta-ba-ina=hó̲ | \gls NEG-SM2-be_at=LOC16 | \glt ‘She is not here.’

Knowledge Point: The class 17 locative clitic =ko, is used to refer to a direction, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref446065865}), or to a general location, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref446065874}).
Content 1: \gsrc kàtóndìkò | \gll ka-a-tónd-i=ko | \gls NEG-SM1-look-NEG=LOC17 | \glt ‘She doesn’t look that way.’
Content 2: \gsrc kàndíhàràngákò | \gll ka-ndí̲-haHr-ang-a=kó̲ | \gls PST.IPFV-SM1SG-live-HAB-FV=LOC17 | \glt ‘I used to live there.’

Knowledge Point: The class 18 locative clitic =mo, is used to refer to a location inside, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99094232}), or to a movement away from inside, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99094242}).
Content 1: \gsrc yènkéː náàkàráːràmò | \gll ye-nkéː ná̲-a-a-ka-ráːr-a=mo | \gls NP1-one PST-SM1-DIST-sleep-FV=LOC18 | \glt ‘He slept alone in there.’
Content 2: \gsrc àkùbútùkàmò | \gll a-aku-bútuk-a=mo | \gls SM1-NPST.IPFV-run-FV=LOC18 | \glt ‘He ran out of it.’

Knowledge Point: In addition to their locative function, locative clitics can also be used with a partitive function. This has also been noted for a number of other Bantu languages, including Bemba (\citealt{MartenKula2014}), Kanincin \citep{DevosEtAl2010}, and others (\citealt{PersohnDevos2017}). In Fwe, all three locative clitics can have a partitive interpretation. The partitive use of the class 16 clitic =ho is illustrated in (\ref{bkm:Ref494450771}), indicating that the speaker did not sell all the cattle, but only some of them. In (\ref{bkm:Ref494450803}), the class 17 clitic =ko is used to indicate that only a part of the intended salary is given, not the whole amount. In (\ref{bkm:Ref494450773}), the class 18 clitic =mo is used to stress that the addressee should take some, not everything.
Content 1: \gsrc zòbírè bùryó nìndáùrìsáhò | \gll ∅-zi-o=bíre bu-ryó ni-ndí̲-a-ur-is-a=hó̲ | \gls COP-PP10-CON=two NP14-only REM-SM1SG-PST-buy-CAUS-FV=LOC16 | \glt ‘It is only two of them that I sold.’
Content 2: \gsrc bàshìkùhàkó àkàháfù | \gll ba-shiH-ku-haH-a=kó̲ a-ka-hafú | \gls SM2-PER-OM2SG-give-FV=LOC17 AUG-NP12-half | \glt ‘They still only give you half of it.’

Knowledge Point: The class 17 locative clitic has an additional function of marking a polite request, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref492041509}). This function is also seen with the class 17 nominal prefix (see \sectref{bkm:Ref452049189} for examples).
Content 1: \gsrc ndìshàká kùkàrìmàkò ècìŋórìsó ꜝcákò | \gll ndi-shak-á̲ ku-karim-a=ko e-ci-ŋórisó ci-akó | \gls SM1SG-want-FV INF-borrow-FV=LOC17 AUG-NP7-pen PP7-POSS2SG | \glt ‘I want to borrow your pen, please.’
